author: Katie Akin
title: Ron DeSantis slams Nikki Haley for omitting slavery as Civil War cause
text: Katie Akin ANKENY, Iowa — Republican presidential candidate Ron DeSantis slammed opponent Nikki Haley for giving "a really incomprehensible word salad" answer when she was asked in [New Hampshire what caused the Civil War.](/story/news/politics/elections/2023/12/28/nikki-haley-slavery-civil-war/72046352007/) During a Wednesday town hall in Berlin, New Hampshire, a voter asked Haley, “What was the cause of the United States Civil War?” “Well, don’t come with an easy question or anything," Haley responded. "I mean, I think the cause of the Civil War was basically how the government was going to run. The freedoms and what people could and couldn’t do.” Haley never mentioned slavery in her answer, drawing backlash from her Republican and Democratic rivals. On Thursday, Haley said "of course the Civil War was about slavery," and she [suggested the question came from a Democratic plant in the audience.](/story/news/politics/elections/2023/12/28/nikki-haley-defends-civil-war-answer-blames-democratic-plant/72048362007/) DeSantis was quick to criticize Haley at an Ankeny campaign stop Thursday morning. He told reporters she is "not a candidate that's ready for prime time." "The minute that she faces any kind of scrutiny, she tends to cave," DeSantis said. "I think that that's what you saw yesterday. Not that difficult to identify and acknowledge the role slavery played in the Civil War, and yet that seemed to be something that was really difficult." DeSantis claimed the abolition of slavery was a "partisan achievement." "The Republican Party was founded to put a stop to the growth of slavery in this country. And the abolition of slavery was — and to this day, remains — the party's top achievement," he said. But DeSantis faced his own gauntlet of questions about slavery and the legacy of the Civil War. A reporter asked about a curriculum standard approved in Florida that "includes how slaves developed skills which, in some instances, could be applied for their personal benefit." The language earned Florida and DeSantis scorn, including from U.S. Sen. Tim Scott, who at the time was a presidential candidate before later dropping out. DeSantis cut off the reporter's question about the standard: "That's a fake narrative," he said. "We've now had a whole semester that's happened. Have you seen examples of (teachers) saying what the media was saying this summer? No." DeSantis said the standard was "bastardized" intentionally to "create a narrative." "Florida's standards were written largely by African-Americans, and they were accurate, and any of those narratives are false," he said. Another reporter asked DeSantis to comment on Jacksonville, Florida, Mayor Donna Deegan's removal of a Confederate monument. "I'm opposed to taking down statues," DeSantis said. "The idea that we're going to just erase history is wrong." USA Today contributed reporting. Katie Akin is a politics reporter for the Register. Reach her at [kakin@registermedia.com](mailto:kakin@registermedia.com). Follow her on Twitter at @katie_akin .

author: ETtoday新聞雲
title: 金門縣狹小巷弄古蹟多田野火警頻繁　金消赴南消取經細水霧幫浦消防車！
text:
▲金門縣消防局6日由副局長陳國瑋率員，前往台南市消防局拜訪，由消防局展示全國首創研發之幫浦消防車，體現消防工作不分區域，一同追求成長與卓越的打火兄弟情誼。（圖／記者林東良翻攝，下同）
記者林東良／台南報導
金門縣消防局6日由副局長陳國瑋率員，前往台南市消防局拜訪，由消防局展示全國首創研發之幫浦消防車，體現消防工作不分區域，一同追求成長與卓越的打火兄弟情誼，該車將專門運用於機動車輛上之設備，安裝至現有的災情勘查皮卡車上，令現場觀摩人員對於其優異的搶救效能，無不留下深刻的印象。
經改裝後的幫浦消防車，跟傳統消防車比較，具有非常高的機動性，能有游刃有餘的穿梭於狹小巷弄，即使面對金門地區如迷宮般的窄巷也能暢行無阻的駛入，而且能單人完成60公尺的布線，更是相當節省消防人力，以最快的速度將水線拉進起火居室出水搶救。除此之外，金門縣更是全國古蹟密度最高的縣市，然而細水霧設備具有低衝擊性及高效省水的特點，以水霧將起火處籠罩包覆，快速降溫達到滅火的功效，避免水線的衝擊導致古蹟建築物損害，其每分鐘出水更僅有22公升，相較於傳統動輒數百公升的出水量，能大幅度減少救災時所衍生的水損，而對於田野雜草火警得以高效節水的方式救災，更是十分適合。最後更實地示範大面積油類火災的滅火性能，讓具有十分容易回火復燃特性的油類火災，在經由細水霧搭配滅火藥劑，得以確實且快速的被徹底撲滅。
台南市長黃偉哲表示，消防局一直以來都為市民朋友的安全而努力，能夠得到鄰近縣市的青睞千里前來取經，共同分享創新研發成果正是教學相長的體現，透過進一步的交流研討，更能激盪出火花。期盼所有消防人員在第一線衝鋒陷陣時，都能非常安全且有效率。一同提升消防救災之能量，以維護百姓生命財產之安全，使每位民眾住得安心，打造一座宜居、安全的城市。
台南市消防局長李明峯表示，消防局肩負保障市民安全的重責大任，隨著科技日新月異，火災類型跟以往相較有延燒非常快速、熱釋率高及更難撲滅的特性，消防局也必須跟與時俱進以提升救災技術增進搶救量能，期待消防局團隊可以百尺竿頭繼續往更高的目標邁進。

author: Simon Chamberlain
title: Diversity in farming and food at Grounded Australia in Tasmania | The Land | NSW
text: Author, food critic, and television series host Matthew Evans adds another arrow to an already crowded quiver by hosting Grounded Australia on Fat Pig Farm, the 32-hectare farm he runs with his wife Sadie in Tasmania's Huon Valley. It will be held on December 4 and 5, and Matthew says it's no coincidence that World Soils Day is December 5. He said the decision to establish Grounded was inspired by attending Groundswell 2023 in the UK and has received the blessing from the British event to host a similar event down under. He says Grounded Australia is re-imagining farmer learning by running multiple talks and demonstrations on farms for farmers organised by farmers. Over the two days, there will be roughly 40-hour-long sessions in three large marquees with a fantastic and inspiring range of speakers. You can click [here](https://groundedaustralia.com.au/speakers/) to see a list of the proposed speakers. One of the many speaker highlights is UK farmer and author James Rebanks, who lives in the Lake District, where his family has lived and worked for more than 600 years. His number one bestselling debut, The Shepherd's Life, won the Lake District Book of the Year, was shortlisted for the Wainwright and Ondaatje prizes, and has been translated into sixteen languages. Another top-tier speaker will be Dan Kittredge, an organic farmer for more than 30 years and the founder and executive director of the Bionutrient Food Association (BFA), a non-profit whose mission is to "increase quality in the food supply." Matthew said Dan is known as one of the leading proponents of "nutrient density," and he works to demonstrate the connections between soil health, plant health, and human health. Iain and Di Haggerty farm more than 26,315 hectares in the West Australian wheatbelt, beginning their journey in 1994 when they bought about 660ha of land. They realised their system was vulnerable to dry seasons; input costs were steadily increasing without corresponding increases in productivity, maximising crop production in dry years had become a real struggle, and hard pans in their soils severely restricted root growth. So, the Haggerty started researching biologically based farming systems to increase their soil's microbial population, nutrient availability, and moisture-holding capacity. What followed was a massive learning curve combining and adapting some of the world's best ecological knowledge with much ground truthing and extension in harsh Western Australian semi-arid agricultural zone conditions. Matthew said that to cater to land stewards' thirst for knowledge, thought-provoking discussions on a range of topics should be held in a safe, supportive space where a diversity of views is treated with respect. He added that these talks will aim at different levels of prior knowledge while offering hope and plenty of chances for social interaction. "That's because farming is the answer to so many of the world's ills, be it climate, soils, biodiversity, or human health," he said. Another exciting speaker is Dr Anita Fleming, the research manager of the Lincoln University Integral Health Dairy Farm near Christchurch, New Zealand. Matthew said Dr Fleming's expertise focused on ruminant nutrition, agricultural system design, and identification of connections between pastures, livestock, and consumers. He said Dr Fleming and her team, using metabolomic techniques, have identified metabolic signatures pertaining to different pastures that are identifiable in not only grazing cattle but also humans who consume beef. "Anita was drawn into agricultural science following a rural upbringing. She also runs a successful dairy business in mid-Canterbury with her husband and is a practical thinker who is merging practical on-farm experience with cutting-edge, innovative science." Fat Pig Farm is a revitalised old apple farm that was the stage for many of Matthew's SBS television series episodes. It also plays a role in his explorations for better ways to widen the production scope for small acreages. He is trialling wheat under minimum or no-till processes but without knockdown chemicals like the glyphosate family (see the above image where the wheat is on Matthew's right and a 13-species pasture is on Sadie's left). A small strip of wheat was sown onto the ground that was flail-mowed. He says growing wheat is a natural fit for poultry and pig production but has many challenges. In the region south of Hobart, for example, only one header is available for harvesting. It's also part of a broader conversation about what suits the best methods of producing nutrient-dense food (part of the topics Dan Kittredge will explore). Organic, regenerative or conventional farming systems are close in levels of nutrient density. "The only correlation is biological activity, how much life there is in your soil," Matthew said. "That's what defines the end production." Grounded will run on December 4 and 5, with tickets now on sale. Click [here](https://groundedaustralia.com.au/) to read more about the event.
